He had to learn a number of technologies that were new to him and he learned these skills quickly and applied them with aplomb. The work he did really required multiple people but we were resource-constrained and Andy was able to take on this large volume of work and was able to deal with ambiguity and multiple inputs efficiently and highly effectively. He built strong relationships across my team and partner teams which enabled him to effectively execute his tasks. He was patient and proactive, he dealt with multiple personalities effectively and he accommodated the needs of the team with an effectiveness that I've rarely seen in my many years at Microsoft. He became an integral part of the team and his work enabled us to complete our job in a way that would have been near impossible without it. I would not hesitate to hire Andy again and have found him to be both a pleasure to work with and a highly effective team member. I have no doubt that Andy will be a key and strong contributor in whatever role he finds himself. Wake-up Project Engineer Company Name Ecole Centrale Paris Dates Employed Sep 2010 – Apr 2011 Employment Duration 8 mos For parents of large families, the beginning of each day can be difficult each child has to wake-up at a different time and they must adapt to wake them one by one. It would be much easier to program the clock for each child the day before or even a few days early and no longer have trouble with the awakening of his children. This project aims to provide a solution to solve this issue. This solution will include Alarm clocks programmed remotely from a Server where you can program and edit the schedule for each alarm clock. They needed to know how many people were living in each barangay and that information was not available from the Philippine government. More Actions Suhail has a account Suhail Shergill Head of R&D and Innovation Lead; Technical Advisor Scotiabank Clemson University Toronto, Canada Area 500+ 500+ connections Connect Pending Invitation Sent We live in a world where we have more data than we know what to do with. The challenge lies in building software that generates actionable insights; that is robust, scalable, extensible, maintainable; and that empowers the subject matter experts (SMEs) of the problem domain in question. I bootstrap, grow, and lead teams for the above; to understand the "how,"​ read on.Having lead a number of cross-functional initiatives with multiple stakeholders (business strategy, technology, and various product lines), I am no stranger to leading teams to design and implement generic solutions that address the various pain points (in the present and future). I bridge the gap between the high-level business view and the technical trenches.With a strong background and extensive expertise in bootstrapping, growing and leading a development team (distributed or otherwise), I have spearheaded innovation in building robust fault-tolerant platforms operating at Big Data scale, which provide actionable insights to various functional units within the business.To facilitate the above, I have employed various techniques for:1] establishing end-product requirements and specifications and building and executing a cross-functional roadmap that ensures early feedback and timely delivery to key stakeholders2] ensuring program correctness, including, but not limited to, encoding proof via types, auto-generating tests to verify invariants and laws, and verifying properties via model checkers and model finders. Academic experience in writing provably correct code (modulo extraction and compilation) via interactive theorem provers such as Coq3] managing code complexity: functional programming, extensible and reusable abstractions, embedding and interpreting domain-specific languagesWith a passion for R&D, I maintain strong ties in the industry and research communities; I am active in local meet-ups, open-source initiatives, and act as a technical advisor to startups. Director of Innovation Company Name Mediative Dates Employed Nov 2014 – May 2016 Employment Duration 1 yr 7 mos Location Toronto, Canada Area Principal architect and scientist responsible for research and development activities aimed at building an actionable recommendation platform to aid human decision-making tasks. Currently, the primary use cases are of providing actionable insights and automation to:- Ensure data quality across multiple noisy datasets with millions of entries per day- Optimize campaigns run on auction networks- Enable senior executives to make informed strategic decisions impacting tens of millions of dollars in annual revenueTo deliver the above, I have been primarily responsible for:- Growing and managing a distributed team (10+ developers, architects and project managers spread across Canada from the West Coast to the east) focused on development spanning software engineering (full-stack), big data, system administration and assorted R&D activities in an agile workflow.- Architecting and helping implement the solution for scaling up and automating human decision-making focused on principles of extensibility, resiliency and scalability. Specifically for data quality, this involves architecting a platform that tracks and helps maintain the validity of numerous reports by being robust to assorted failures and incorporating various automated and semi-automated data recovery mechanisms. For the campaign optimization use case, it involves architecting a private exchange (and associated automation layer) that is able to optimize across different inventory channels (display, search, etc.), respect campaign constraints, optimize towards campaign KPIs, and share learnings from across campaigns.- Providing strategic technical insight into multiple business acquisition decisions (of the order of $50-100 million each) to help shape the future (5yr and beyond) roadmap.- Lending technical expertise in helping conduct vendor research for solution acceleration. - Various planning, cost forecasting and other activities relating to defining business case and mandate. Media (2) This position has 2 media Scaling human decision-making in online advertising Scaling human decision-making in online advertising This media is a link Fields Institute Video: Scaling human decision-making in online advertising Fields Institute Video: Scaling human decision-making in online advertising This media is a link Data Architect Company Name Mediative Dates Employed Jul 2014 – Nov 2014 Employment Duration 5 mos Location Montreal, Canada Area Hired as the resident data architect, I quickly became the principal scientist responsible for architecting a solution to scale up and automate human decision-making tasks pertaining to (advertisement) campaign optimization.Conducted interviews with key members of the organization to identify pain points. Devised the architecture (both from a data model as well as software architecture perspective) for a general-purpose (semi-automated) platform to aid human decision-making tasks. Working closely with the VP of platforms and technology, we prepared a project roadmap and communicated this vision to the various business stakeholders. The project won the approval of the CEO of Yellow Pages Group and became one of a handful of key "return to growth" initiatives within YP. Having convinced the business, I then proceeded to create job descriptions and interviewed candidates to fulfill this project's requirements and goals. In recognition of my efforts and demonstrated leadership, I was promoted to the role of Director of Innovation shortly thereafter. Dates Employed 2005 – 2010 Employment Duration 5 yrs Location Burbank, CA Senior Software Engineer, data architect and Yahoo's in-house expert on online fraud detection. Traffic Protection team built online fraud detection solutions which was a core component of Yahoo's advertising platform. The click fraud detection system processed millions of click events per hour and a few billion dollars per year. I focused on designing, architecting, developing innovative and practical algorithms to fight online click fraud. I've designed the majority of TP's complex behavioral filtering algorithms using data mining, statistical, database and cloud computing technologies. The rule based filtering algorithms I designed detected over hundred millions dollars of click fraud per year. During an infamous and large scale industry wide fraud attack (which happened few years ago), my algorithms detected nearly all of the fraud. With the high detection rate, Yahoo didn't have to take down ads in certain field to avoid the attack, like some other large search companies had to do.Technology stack: Hadoop, Pig, C++, Perl, Oracle, SQL, Bash, Awk Education Katholieke Universiteit Leuven Degree Name M.S. Education University of California, Berkeley Degree Name Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) Field Of Study Physical Chemistry Dates attended or expected graduation 2006 – 2011 Activities and Societies: Iota Sigma Pi (Women's Chemistry Honor Society) Studied dynamics is supercooled liquids (glassy systems) to understand the discrepency between the macroscopic, solid-like(observed) behavior of glass as rigid and its microscopic structure (liquid like/disordered). Compared transport proporties (diffusion constant, relaxation time, and viscosity) of over 55 molecular glassformers showing that all the data can be collapsed onto a single, master curve thus highlighting glass universality. My vision was a centralized organization embedded in cross-functional project groups, leveraging cutting-edge infrastructure and tools, and drawing from a common warehouse that would serve as our single source of truth.I decided to move on in the summer of 2016, at a time when the data science org had over 100 members and they mapped to every strategic initiative in the company. More Actions Jeff has a account Jeff Winchell Practical Data Scientist Many Interesting Places Harvard University Gainesville, Florida Area 360 360 connections Connect Pending Invitation Sent I Question Therefore I AmCuriosity, Creativity, Skepticism and Grit are essential to a successful data scientist. I usethese character traits to ask a few good questions to increase the value of your value proposition.As a sometimes entrepreneur myself, I understand and apply the 80/20 rule to all problems asthere are too many valuable applications of data science to justify perfecting just one problem.My expertise is in making managers more successful by finding solutions to their most challenging known problems as well as ones they hadn’t realized they needed to solve. I’ve also helped them see when the solution is to pull the plug on an expensive endeavor. I’ve found solutions using technologies pushed beyond the industry’s known limits of size and speed and also developed novel, effective forecasting solutions using simple statistics and even manual data acquisition.You can do wonders with experienced insight constantly refreshed by a youth-like exploration of the possibilities, and I’m ready to do that for you.Executive summary:o Data scientist with decades of success in asking great questions and finding their solution.o SQL and performance guruo Highly accelerated assimilation of new skills, creation of methods when none exist and tactical exploitation of legacy solutions when best suited.o Passion for deep problems tempered by the agile practice that shipping is a feature.o Comfortable talking with c-levels about a forecast’s strategic implications, asking highly cited researchers about their seminal works, and describing the essence of complex issues to novices.o Strong preference for working on great teams, or helping develop those not yet there.Windows Tools: R, SQL Server, Python, Java and many other OOP, BI and DBMS products, some recently developed, some, not so much. (www.canirank.com) helps marketers improve efficiency and effectiveness by identifying high impact SEO changes.ODI's second product, Pretarget.com, leverages machine learning to identify, score, and classify potential B2B customers before they begin searching for your product or services.ODI's third product, GrowthAI.com monitors marketing data for your website and competitors, then uses a predictive analytics-based recommendation engine to score each opportunity according to projected value, difficulty, and likelihood of success.Previously Bentley served as CEO of Sedo.com and Chief Strategy Officer of Sedo GmbH, helping grow the company from startup to 9 figures revenue, 140 employees, and successful exit via reverse IPO. Media (3) This position has 3 media Pretarget.com Pretarget.com This media is an image Keyword difficulty & SEO competitive analysis tool - CanIRank Keyword difficulty & SEO competitive analysis tool - CanIRank This media is a link Growth AI: Find growth opportunities hidden in your marketing data Growth AI: Find growth opportunities hidden in your marketing data This media is a link Founder & Chief Scientist Company Name CanIRank? - SEO Software for Competitive SEOs Dates Employed Nov 2010 – Present Employment Duration 6 yrs 7 mos Location San Francisco Bay Area CanIRank uses the power of machine learning to turn your SEO and online marketing data into specific actionable steps that you can take to improve your rankings and grow your traffic. As Chief Scientist I built CanIRank's data models using neural net and support vector machine algorithms. The resulting models can predict the ordering of Google results with nearly 60% accuracy, over twice as accurate as other SEO tools. Specifically, that will be machine learning and AI-enabled software. CanIRank is already at the forefront of this insanely complex movement and while everyone else is still scrambling to figure out how it works, Matt has already managed to package all of it up into a streamlined application that a novice marketer can figure out in a day. Matt is extremely considerate, listens intently to (and actively requests) your input, and is willing to mentor and pass on his considerable knowledge. More Actions Benoît has a premium account Click to upgrade to Premium 3rd degree connection3rd Benoît Brookens III (Dr. Big Data) CEO, Founder at Accrue, Inc. | Looking for Superstars Civil Air Patrol Columbia University - Columbia Business School Hong Kong 500+ 500+ connections Connect Pending Invitation Sent Benoît Brookens III, more affectionately Dr. BigData is an award-winning data scientist and serial entrepreneur. Benoît is the CEO and Co-Founder of the IBM-backed FinTech (financial technology) firm Accrue Inc. He learned to type before he could write, as one of the earliest participants of M.I.T. Media Lab's Lifelong Kindergarten in the early 1990s. In 2002, he pioneered multi-class IP Web Hosting as a teenager, with his first start-up Dataracks. As one of the youngest quantitative traders at a Swiss Bank, Benoît was ahead of the data science industry, leveraging algorithms on datasets that materialized during the 2000s decade. He was a participant at the world’s first Data Science Summit. After securing the trademark “Apps for Insight” through his incubator nuOctave Inc., he has been focused on the democratization of data to compel better decision making. Benoît currently sits on the advisory board of Tradestation Securities Inc. and is noted as one of the United Kingdom’s Trade & Investment 2016 FinTech Delegation. I would happily hire Bo again. I ate lunch in the nurses office a lot of the time, I had breakdowns in bathrooms, and I got scolded by my teachers for the small rituals I often needed to do just to get through the school day. Entering high school, I never even imagined being able to survive college and even my school counselor advised me not to pursue a bachelors degree. I couldn't live with the idea that this disorder would define my life and education, so I began learning ways to manage it. More Actions Randy has a account Randy Olson Senior Data Scientist at University of Pennsylvania University of Pennsylvania Michigan State University Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 500+ 500+ connections First and foremost, I’m a senior data scientist working with Prof. Jason H. Moore at the University of Pennsylvania Institute for Biomedical Informatics developing state-of-the-art machine learning algorithms to solve biomedical problems. I also occasionally collaborate with the media and private companies on projects that I believe are important, so please feel free to contact me me if you think I would be a good fit for one of your projects.I specialize in artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data visualization, although I’m always learning something new to make myself more useful to my clients and collaborators. I regularly write about my latest work on my personal blog, where I’ve become known for computing optimal road trips around the world and solving Where’s Waldo?, among many other creative applications of machine learning. My work has been featured all over the world and in the news, including the New York Times, Wired, FiveThirtyEight, and much more.I work tirelessly to promote open and reproducible science, leading by example and openly publishing my work on GitHub and open access journals. I’m also passionate about training the next generation of data scientists to be more efficient, effective, and collaborative in their work, and do so by writing online tutorials, teaching hands-on workshops, and mentoring local students in my research specialties. If you would like to commission me to teach a workshop or give a talk in your area, please get in touch.You can follow me on Twitter (https://twitter.com/randal_olson) or Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/RandalSOlson), where I post new data visualizations every day. (The data visualizations aren’t always created by me.) I’m also a community leader for the popular data visualization subreddit reddit.com/r/DataIsBeautiful, which now serves over 2 million unique readers every month.Please take a look at my web site and blog below to get an idea of what I've been working lately. Moore's lab at Penn's Institute for Biomedical Informatics. At Penn, I will continue developing state-of-the-art machine learning algorithms with a focus on biomedical applications. I will also continue aiding Prof. Moore in developing a biomedical visualization laboratory, which will offer machine learning and data analysis as a service to PennMed faculty and physicians. Postdoctoral Researcher Company Name University of Pennsylvania Dates Employed Jun 2015 – Jul 2016 Employment Duration 1 yr 2 mos Location Philadelphia, PA I joined Prof. Jason H. Moore's research lab at Penn's Institute for Biomedical Informatics. At Penn, I developed state-of-the-art machine learning algorithms with a focus on biomedical applications. I also be aided Prof. Moore in laying the groundwork for a biomedical visualization laboratory that will be used as a collaborative research space by Penn's medical school. Graduate Research Assistant Company Name Michigan State University Dates Employed Aug 2011 – May 2015 Employment Duration 3 yrs 10 mos Location East Lansing, MI I spent 4 years working on my dual major Ph.D. at Michigan State University working with Prof. Christoph Adami. During my time there, I established a high-performance C++ platform for studying the evolution of intelligent animal behavior over long, evolutionary timescale. With this platform, I published several articles in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings to share what I learned about the evolution of cooperation. Computer Scientist Company Name Warner Robins Air Logistics Center Dates Employed Jun 2010 – Aug 2011 Employment Duration 1 yr 3 mos Location Warner Robins, GA I worked as a civilian employee for the Air Force developing tools for the Electronic Warfare division. My time here was primarily spent as a software engineer in a larger software development team. During this time, I developed a novel method for two-legged robots to learn to walk without supervision. Used linear programming (CPLEX and COIN-OR), object oriented programming in VB.NET, life cycle assessment, engineering economics, modeling to generate alternatives, multi-objective programming, etc. Research Assistant Company Name North Carolina State University Dates Employed Aug 1994 – Jul 1999 Employment Duration 5 yrs Developed a quantitative framework to aid in decision making for integrated municipal solid waste (MSW) management. Developed the mathematical model to solve problem that caused the previous models to be time-consuming and overly complex. The model uses a flexible framework to represent many site-specific issues and considerations. It incorporates both cost and environmental objectives. The environmental objectives are defined in terms of life cycle inventories of energy and emissions (of carbon monoxide, fossil- and biomass-derived carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxides, sulfur oxides, particulate matter [PM], and PM10) and greenhouse gases) associated with MSW management strategies. The application of this model was demonstrated through realistic hypothetical case studies. Several MSW management scenarios of typical interest to U.S. municipalities were studied. Through these illustrative applications, the flexibility and capabilities of the model were demonstrated. Principal Scientist Company Name Siemens Medical Solutions Dates Employed Nov 2004 – Jan 2015 Employment Duration 10 yrs 3 mos I led groups that developed & commercialized products in three broad areas. 1. Our group developed several computer aided diagnosis (CAD) products that automatically identify early stage cancer of the Breast, Lung, and Colon based on X-ray, and CT images. These systems help radiologists improve their sensitivity of detecting early stage cancers by up to 30%. 2. We developed products that personalized therapy for rectal cancer & non small-cell lung cancer by predicting & optimizing outcomes as a function of the treatment for each patient. 3. We developed products that improved documented adherence to best-practice treatment guidelines. In particular we developed data mining systems that combine all available structured and unstructured data for a patient, to identify & eliminate gaps in care & documentation. These systems help hospitals achieve >95% documented compliance with best-practice treatment-guidelines (compared to national averages of 54%), while reducing the staff required for data collection by 50%. Metro Area Started in 1989, KDD is the oldest & largest data mining conference worldwide. We pioneered “Big Data”, “Data Science”, and “Predictive Analytics” solutions before these names existed – some of the first & most highly cited research papers on these topics were published in our conference. Other notable innovations that originated in our conference include crowd sourcing; Large scale data mining competitions with over 10,000 participants, personalized advertising eg. on Google, graph mining algorithms that power Facebook & LinkedIn, and recommender systems used by Netflix, Amazon etc. After 25 years and an explosive growth in this industry, we are still the home for the latest cutting-edge research in these topics.I started the Industry Practice track of invited talks @ KDD 2010. First, Austin's knowledge of statistical methods is unparalleled. When trying to find a small signal in messy data there are very few data scientists who actually have the skill set to understand the quality of signal in hand. Austin is one of them. To be more specific, Austin's statistical knowledge coupled with his coding skills enable him to conquer any business problem. Second, Austin is rare in that he is a data scientist who possesses legitimate interest in solving business problems. Many data scientists are enthralled by algorithms and the latest "Big Data" tools and therefore use them just for the sake of using them with little thought towards their applicability to the problem in hand. Suffice to say, Austin is very conscience of using the most applicable tools to best solve a given business problem.Third, and arguably the most valuable trait Austin possesses, is the ability to communicate technical results to everyone including sales people and product managers. At Zillow, Austin was able to consistently bring everyone on the same page for a project with major marketplace implications that involved his research in pricing models.There's no question Austin is self-motivated and always learning new skills to improve as a data scientist. I can recall several times where Austin was self-teaching himself software development skills in order to assist in translating his technical work into a production environment. Chandran Mudhliar Advisory Consultant at Deloitte & Touche LLP July 2, 2015, Artem was Chandran’s mentor I served as a technical supervisor for Chandran's capstone project for the University of Washington Information School. The project entailed using Zillow's raw consumer search data in order to mine relationships between zip codes. After explaining the problem Zillow was interested in solving, Chandran and his group excelled in developing a solution and presenting it in terms anyone can understand. With minimal guidance, the group devised a creative solution towards clustering zip codes based on network graph algorithms. The group's ability to fully solve an open ended project in a limited timeframe was very impressive and speaks to the level of project management and technical expertise in the group. Zillow is currently pursuing a few zip code clustering ideas presented by Chandran in the future work section of the capstone. Given Chandran's performance on the capstone project I am extremely excited to see the kind of work Chandran will produce throughout his career. There is no doubt in my mind Chandran has the technical chops and self-discipline to contribute towards the solution of any data science problem in any industry. More Actions Gideon has a account Gideon Mann Head of Data Science / CTO Office at Bloomberg LP Bloomberg LP University of Massachusetts Amherst Greater New York City Area 500+ 500+ connections Connect Pending Invitation Sent Gideon Mann is the head of Data Science at Bloomberg, guiding the strategic direction for machine learning, natural language processing, and search on the core terminal. At Bloomberg, his team has worked on the company-wide data science platform, natural language question answering, and deep learning text processing, among other products. He also founded and leads the Data for Good Exchange (bloomberg.com/d4gx), an annual conference on data science applications for social good and is a core member of the Shift Commission on Work, Workers and Technology (shiftcommission.work). Mann graduated Brown University in 1999 and subsequently received a Ph.D. from The Johns Hopkins University in 2006. His focus at Hopkins was natural language processing with a dissertation on multi-document fact extraction and fusion. After a short post-doc at UMass-Amherst working on problems in weakly supervised machine learning, he moved to Google Research in NYC in 2007. In addition to academic research, his team at Google built core internal machine learning libraries, and publicly released the Google Prediction API and coLaboratory, a collaborative iPython application. He joined Bloomberg's leadership team in the CTO department in 2014. I developed an algorithm that uses expert knowledge and social-science theory to make more accurate predictions of political contests than what experts make themselves. The algorithm can be rapidly deployed, and it produces a measure of uncertainty so decisionmakers can assess risk and the quality of the prediction. My models proved more accurate than the company’s existing gold standard by at least 30 percent. Unlike their predecessors, these models also produce measures of uncertainty so decisionmakers can know how precise they are and calculate probabilities of outcomes. They did well enough that we started exporting them to units overseas. In 2000, he received a Ph.D. in microelectronics. He has published over 170 journals and proceeding papers, 2 Wireless Standards , 2 book chapters, gave numerous invited talks and organized numerous workshops at international conferences. He holds 8 patents and 29 invention disclosures. His research interests include CMOS, SOI and SiGe RF and millimeter-waves circuit design, Neural Network and Genetic Algorithms based designs, advanced 3D integration and antenna packaging technologies, RF and millimeter-waves embedded passives (antenna arrays, filters) design, RF-MEMS and micro-machining techniques. Our work is mostly in Python, relying on scikit-learn’s pipelines and gridsearch to build our models and Spotify’s Luigi for our deployments. We have no mandate beyond finding the most valuable place we can apply our skill-sets. When first coming on board to Braintree, I was challenged to define the role of Data Science at Braintree and tasked with hiring a team. Within three months I built a new interview process, and six months after its implementation we have a fully staffed data science team. I have selected our projects, lead our deployments, and defined our successes with measurable KPIs. As one of the few specialists on the developer side, I lead both formal and informal events to educate departments about data science and its applications at Braintree. I've developed relationships with our PayPal counterparts and have begun exploring opportunities in integrating their work into our process.
